The mysteries of actress Isabelle Adjani's vocation
subhead: 'Adjani, The Famous Stranger' (1/6). Nothing seemed to predestine her to become one of the greatest stars of French cinema. Yet the young actress, born to an Algerian father and a German mother, experienced a meteoric rise. She made her debut on stage at barely 17 years old and quickly transitioned to film.

Serbia's protest movement spreads to small towns
subhead: The anti-corruption movement that began in universities in November 2024 is spreading. In Valjevo, law enforcement officers beat and arrested protesters while masked men, apparently sent by those in power, ransacked businesses owned by President Aleksandar Vucic's opponents.
byline: By Jean-Baptiste Chastand (Pancevo, Valjevo (Serbia), special correspondent)

title: Spike in suspicious incidents in Iran fuels fears of a simmering war
subhead: Iranians remain on edge two months after the end of the 12-day war, worried about renewed fighting with Israel and burdened by inflation and water and power shortages.

title: Women's Rugby World Cup: France enters tournament aiming for title
subhead: France kicks off its World Cup campaign on Saturday in Exeter against Italy. The third-place regulars now have their sights set on outright victory.

title: From Brittany to the Alps, French cities restrict holiday homes
subhead: Faced with the challenge of housing the residents of highly touristic or attractive cities, some mayors have decided to ban the construction of new vacation properties.

title: Death of French streamer: Behind Kick, an Australian crypto casino and two young billionaires
subhead: The livestreaming platform began as an offshoot of one of the world's largest online gambling sites: Stake. From the outset, lax moderation was part of its DNA.

title: Being a writer in the digital age? James Baldwin 'seemed free in ways we no longer can be'
subhead: 'Letters from America' (6/6). Writer and journalist Thomas Chatterton Williams envies the great American author's bohemian, technology-free existence, despite the chaos it represented.

title: In 'Kolkhoze,' Emmanuel Carrère becomes his mother's son
subhead: In his new book, the French author reflects on his often tumultuous relationship with his late mother, Hélène Carrère d'Encausse, and explores what he owes her. This major work addresses themes of death, love and writing.
